Summary
Critical Security Fix: Replace direct call with in API service
Issue: Authentication tokens weren't using consistent clock skew compensation across all API calls
Solution: Ensures all authentication requests use the centralized clock skew compensation logic
Changes
: Updated method to use
Security Impact
High Priority: Fixes inconsistent authentication token generation
Scope: All authenticated API requests now use consistent timing compensation
Backward Compatible: No breaking changes to API contracts
Test Plan
✅ Clock skew compensation logic verified
✅ Authentication flow maintains existing behavior
✅ Token validation structure preserved
🤖 Generated with Claude Code

Summary by CodeRabbit
Bug Fixes

Fewer auth failures from device/server clock drift; clock-skew detection, sanity checks, and skew-aware retry delays reduce unexpected 401s.
Token retrieval now uses a compensated, skew-aware flow for consistent Authorization headers; test-auth bypass removed.
Tests

Added comprehensive matrix tests covering token retrieval, clock-skew scenarios, timing delays, and malformed-token cases.
Documentation

Added PR guidelines detailing token compensation patterns, TDD matrix, and security/performance practices.

Walkthrough
Implements a clock-skew–aware authentication flow in api.service.ts: token acquisition now uses a compensated path that may wait when client clock is behind, 401 handling processes server-reported clock-skew, retry delays account for detected skew, and tests add matrix coverage for compensated-token scenarios. Public API unchanged.

Changes
Cohort / File(s)    Summary
Auth token compensation & retry logic
mvp_site/frontend_v2/src/services/api.service.ts    - getAuthHeaders() now uses getCompensatedToken(false) for token retrieval
- Added private getCompensatedToken(forceRefresh) with clock-skew wait when client is behind and token structure validation
- Integrated handleClockSkewError(...) and detectClockSkew usage on server-reported skew
- On 401 responses, skew handling is invoked before computing retry delay
- calculateRetryDelay(...) increases delay when significant skew detected
- All internal auth flows use compensated tokens; exported API signatures unchanged
Security/token verification tests
mvp_site/tests/test_v2_frontend_verification.py    - Added TestSecurityTokenMatrix(unittest.TestCase) with matrix scenarios for clock-skew, client-ahead/behind, and force-refresh combinations
- Introduced helper _call_get_compensated_token to simulate compensated-token behavior and validate JWT structure and timing delays
- Added mocks for user/auth/api_service to exercise skew detection, delay behavior, and malformed-token edge cases
- Kept/updated existing red-green verification tests and added documentation-style assertions

This PR implements a critical security fix to ensure consistent authentication token handling across all API calls by replacing direct getIdToken() calls with centralized clock skew compensation logic.

Cohort / File(s)    Summary
Auth token compensation & retry logic
mvp_site/frontend_v2/src/services/api.service.ts    - Replaced direct user.getIdToken() usage with getCompensatedToken(forceRefresh) across internal flows

CodeRabbit has detected other AI code review bot(s) in this pull request and will avoid duplicating their findings in the review comments. This may lead to a less comprehensive review.

Walkthrough
Implements clock-skew–aware token acquisition and retry behavior: token retrieval now goes through a compensated path that may wait when client clock is behind; server-reported clock skew is detected/sanitized and applied before retries; tests add matrix coverage for compensated-token scenarios. Public API unchanged.

Changes
Cohort / File(s)    Summary
Auth token compensation & retry logic
mvp_site/frontend_v2/src/services/api.service.ts    - Replaced direct user.getIdToken() usage with getCompensatedToken(forceRefresh) across internal flows
- getCompensatedToken may wait when client is behind (compensated wait) and validates token shape
- detectClockSkew and handleClockSkewError adjusted to estimate server time, enforce ±3,600,000ms sanity bounds, and ignore/log extreme values
- On 401, clock-skew handling runs before retry delay; calculateRetryDelay includes extra delay when
Security/token verification tests
mvp_site/tests/test_v2_frontend_verification.py    - Added TestSecurityTokenMatrix(unittest.TestCase) exercising matrix of skew (client-ahead/behind), force-refresh combos, and malformed-token edge cases via mocks
- Introduced helper _call_get_compensated_token to simulate timing, enforced waits, and JWT-structure validation
- Kept/updated existing verification tests and added security-focused assertions
Documentation / PR guidelines
docs/pr-guidelines/1547/guidelines.md    - New PR guidelines file documenting patterns, anti-patterns, TDD matrix for clock-skew compensation, performance considerations, and metadata referencing PR #1547
Sequence Diagram(s)


Estimated code review effort
🎯 4 (Complex) | ⏱️ ~45 minutes

Poem
I twitch my nose and count the ticks,
I pause when clocks misplace their ticks.
A patient wait, then hop—token bright,
Locks in time, retries take flight.
Rabbit cheers: skew set right. 🐇✨

Pull Request Overview
This PR implements a critical security fix to ensure consistent authentication token handling across all API calls by replacing direct getIdToken() calls with centralized clock skew compensation logic.

Replaces direct Firebase getIdToken() call with getCompensatedToken(false) method
Ensures all authenticated API requests use consistent timing compensation
Addresses potential authentication inconsistencies due to clock skew issues
